question_content.barrons:question: According to the passage, the natural relationship between government and individual liberty is one of
question_content.barrons:explanation:
inherent opposition.

The author says that the tendency for a government to encroach upon individual liberty to the extent to which it has the power to do so is "almost a natural law" of politics. Thus, government and individual liberty are inherently by their very natures in opposition to one another.

Marked indifference is incorrect. To describe the relationship between government and individual liberty as one of marked indifference (pronounced lack of interest) makes no sense.

Secret collusion is incorrect. To describe the relationship between government and individual liberty as one of secret collusion (hidden conspiracy) makes no sense.

Moderate complicity is incorrect. To describe the relationship between government and individual liberty as one of moderate complicity (limited involvement in wrongdoing) makes no sense.

Fundamental interdependence is incorrect. The author is not describing the relationship between government and individual liberty as one of fundamental interdependence (an essential

mutual reliance).
